title: 107_hr1572
content: The "Worker Amnesty and Opportunity Act of 2001" is a new section added to the Immigration and Nationality Act, providing adjustment of status for certain undocumented and nonimmigrant aliens. The Attorney General can adjust the status of an alien to lawful permanent residence if the alien meets requirements including maintaining continuous physical presence in the United States for at least 10 years. The alien can qualify for adjustment of status to lawful permanent residence if they meet certain qualifications, such as being sponsored by a labor organization for a job with a worker shortage, being eligible for admission as a student at a higher education institution, or being at least 65 years old. The alien must be at least 65 years old and admissible as an immigrant to the United States. Numerical limitations and certain grounds for exclusion do not apply to the adjustment of aliens to lawful permanent resident status under this section. The Attorney General may waive certain provisions of section 212(a) for humanitarian purposes, family unity, or public interest, except for provisions related to criminals. The Attorney General may waive certain provisions of section 212(a) for humanitarian purposes, family unity, or public interest, except for provisions related to criminals. Temporary Stay of Exclusion or Deportation for Certain Applicants is provided by the Attorney General in the case of an alien who presents a nonfrivolous application under subsection (a), allowing the alien to not be excluded or deported until a final determination on the application has been made. Temporary Work Authorization is also granted for certain applicants.
